title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 36 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 36.

questions.question: Who was made king in place of Josiah in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:1 states that the people of the land took Jehoahaz the son of Josiah and made him king in his father's stead in Jerusalem.

questions.question: How long did Jehoahaz reign in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Three months
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 36:2, Jehoahaz reigned three months in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What did the king of Egypt require from the land when he put down Jehoahaz?
options: Hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold
A tribute of wheat and oil
questions.correctAnswer: Hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:3 states that the king of Egypt condemned the land in a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.

questions.question: What new name was given to Eliakim by the king of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: In 2 Chronicles 36:4, the king of Egypt made Eliakim king and changed his name to Jehoiakim.

questions.question: At what age did Jehoiakim begin to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-five years old
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:5 says Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: Who bound Jehoiakim in fetters and carried him to Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:6 states that Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon bound Jehoiakim in fetters to carry him to Babylon.

questions.question: What did Nebuchadnezzar take from the house of the LORD to Babylon?
options: Vessels of the house of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Vessels of the house of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:7 records that Nebuchadnezzar took vessels of the house of the LORD to Babylon and placed them in his temple.

questions.question: How old was Jehoiachin when he began to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Eight years old
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:9 mentions that Jehoiachin was eight years old when he began to reign.

questions.question: Who did Nebuchadnezzar make king after taking Jehoiachin to Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Zedekiah
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 36:10, Nebuchadnezzar made Zedekiah king over Judah and Jerusalem after taking Jehoiachin to Babylon.

questions.question: How long did Zedekiah reign in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Eleven years
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:11 states that Zedekiah reigned eleven years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: Zedekiah humbled himself before Jeremiah the prophet.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:12 explains that Zedekiah did not humble himself before Jeremiah the prophet.

questions.question: True or False: The people mocked and despised the messengers of God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:16 states that the people mocked the messengers of God and despised his words.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD sent the king of the Chaldees to punish the people because of their sins.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:17 states that the LORD brought the king of the Chaldees to punish the people for their sins.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 2 Chronicles 36:20: 'And them that had escaped from the sword carried he away to _______; where they were servants to him and his sons until the reign of the kingdom of Persia.'
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:20 says those who escaped were carried to Babylon, where they served until the kingdom of Persia.

questions.question: Who stirred up the spirit to make a proclamation to build a house in Jerusalem according to 2 Chronicles 36:22?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyrus king of Persia
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 36:22 states that the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia to make a proclamation.

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with perseverance through trials after facing repeated hardships. Based on 2 Chronicles 36, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God disciplines His people out of compassion and for their ultimate good
Trials are a sign that God has abandoned His people
Hardships are always caused by personal sin alone
God never allows suffering for His children
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines His people out of compassion and for their ultimate good
questions.explanation: The LORD sent messengers to the people because He had compassion on them (verses 15-16). Though they mocked the messengers, God's discipline through the king of the Chaldees was to bring them back to Himself (verses 16-17). This shows God's loving discipline in trials.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 36 teach us about humility in leadership?
options: Leaders must humble themselves before God's prophets and obey His word
Leaders should rely only on their own wisdom
Leaders do not need to listen to warnings if they are confident
Humility is optional for those in authority
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must humble themselves before God's prophets and obey His word
questions.explanation: Zedekiah did evil and did not humble himself before Jeremiah, the prophet of the LORD (verse 12), showing the importance of humility and submission to God's guidance by leaders (verses 11-13).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because their prayers seem unanswered. What insight does 2 Chronicles 36 offer about prayer and God's timing?
options: God sends messengers early and repeatedly because of His compassion, even if people do not immediately respond
God answers prayers only when people are perfect
Prayer is ineffective if people continue sinning
God ignores persistent prayer if people rebel
questions.correctAnswer: God sends messengers early and repeatedly because of His compassion, even if people do not immediately respond
questions.explanation: The LORD sent messengers early and often because of His compassion on the people and His dwelling place (verse 15). Despite their rejection, God continued to reach out, highlighting His patience in answering prayer.

questions.question: Based on 2 Chronicles 36, what biblical principle about stewardship can be learned from the fate of the temple treasures?
options: Stewardship of God's house and treasures requires obedience and holiness
Material wealth is the main evidence of God's blessing
Stewardship is only about accumulating riches
questions.correctAnswer: Stewardship of God's house and treasures requires obedience and holiness
questions.explanation: Because the people and priests polluted the house of the LORD with abominations (verse 14), the vessels and treasures were taken to Babylon (verses 7, 18-19), demonstrating the need for holy stewardship.

questions.question: How does the example of Jehoiakim's reign in 2 Chronicles 36 help us understand the importance of integrity and obedience to God?
options: Jehoiakim did evil and was punished by captivity, showing disobedience leads to consequences
Jehoiakim succeeded because he ignored God's commands
Integrity is not important for leadership
Disobedience to God has no real effect on a kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim did evil and was punished by captivity, showing disobedience leads to consequences
questions.explanation: Jehoiakim did evil in the sight of the LORD (verse 5), and Nebuchadnezzar bound him and took him to Babylon (verses 6-7), illustrating the consequences of disobedience.

questions.question: What lesson about forgiveness and repentance can be drawn from the people's reaction to God's messengers in 2 Chronicles 36?
options: Rejecting God’s messengers leads to the LORD’s wrath and judgment
Forgiveness is automatic regardless of response
Repentance is unnecessary if God is merciful
questions.correctAnswer: Rejecting God’s messengers leads to the LORD’s wrath and judgment
questions.explanation: The people mocked and despised the messengers and prophets (verse 16), which caused the wrath of the LORD to arise against them (verses 16-17), showing the danger of rejecting calls to repentance.

questions.question: A new believer asks about God's faithfulness despite Israel’s failures. What encouragement does 2 Chronicles 36 provide?
options: God fulfills His promises even after discipline and exile
God abandons His people forever after sin
God's promises depend on people's perfect obedience
God only cares for one nation and forgets others
questions.correctAnswer: God fulfills His promises even after discipline and exile
questions.explanation: In the first year of Cyrus, God stirred his spirit to fulfill the word spoken by Jeremiah (verses 22-23), demonstrating God's faithfulness to His covenant despite Israel's disobedience.

questions.question: Based on 2 Chronicles 36, what can we learn about the importance of trusting God's timing in restoration?
options: The land kept sabbath for seventy years until restoration, showing God's perfect timing
God delays restoration because He forgets His people
Timing of restoration is random and uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: The land kept sabbath for seventy years until restoration, showing God's perfect timing
questions.explanation: The land remained desolate for seventy years to fulfill the LORD’s word through Jeremiah (verse 21), illustrating patience and trust in God’s appointed timing.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 36, Zedekiah honored his oath to King Nebuchadnezzar and obeyed God's commands.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Zedekiah rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar, breaking his oath and hardening his heart against God (verses 12-13).

questions.question: True or False: The captivity of Judah was a result of their continual sin and rejection of God's warnings, as shown in 2 Chronicles 36.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The people and leaders transgressed greatly (verse 14), mocked God's messengers (verse 16), and as a result, the LORD brought the king of the Chaldees to punish them (verse 17).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Chronicles 36:23, Cyrus king of Persia declared that the LORD God of heaven had given him all the kingdoms of the earth and charged him to build a ______ in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: house
questions.explanation: Cyrus proclaimed that the LORD charged him to build Him a house in Jerusalem (verse 23), indicating God's plan for restoration and worship.

questions.question: How does the exile described in 2 Chronicles 36 teach us about the consequences of collective sin and the need for corporate repentance?
options: The entire nation suffered captivity due to persistent sin and rebellion
Only individuals are held accountable for sin
Corporate sin does not affect a nation
Repentance is unnecessary for national restoration
questions.correctAnswer: The entire nation suffered captivity due to persistent sin and rebellion
questions.explanation: Because all the chiefs of priests and people transgressed greatly (verse 14) and rejected God's messengers (verse 16), the LORD brought the king of the Chaldees to carry them into captivity (verses 17, 20).

questions.question: A believer struggles with contentment during hardship. Based on 2 Chronicles 36, what biblical principle can encourage them?
options: God's discipline serves a purpose and leads to future restoration
Hardships mean God is displeased forever
Contentment is unrelated to spiritual growth
God is indifferent to human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: God's discipline serves a purpose and leads to future restoration
questions.explanation: The exile was to fulfill the LORD's word and allow the land to keep sabbath (verse 21), and eventually God stirred Cyrus to restore His people (verses 22-23), encouraging believers to trust God's plan.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 36 teach about the importance of obedience to God’s word in family and leadership contexts?
options: Obedience leads to blessing and stability, while disobedience leads to judgment and exile
Family and leadership can ignore God's word without consequence
Obedience is only needed in private life
Leadership is about power, not obedience
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to blessing and stability, while disobedience leads to judgment and exile
questions.explanation: Kings like Jehoahaz, Jehoiakim, Jehoiachin, and Zedekiah all did evil and brought judgment on Judah (verses 1-13, 17-20), showing the need for obedience in leadership and family life.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 36, what is the role of prophets in the life of God’s people?
options: To speak God’s word and call for repentance, even when ignored or mocked
To support only the king’s decisions
To remain silent during times of sin
questions.correctAnswer: To speak God’s word and call for repentance, even when ignored or mocked
questions.explanation: Jeremiah and other prophets were sent repeatedly (verse 15), but were mocked and despised (verse 16), showing that prophets faithfully deliver God’s message regardless of response.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 36.

questions.question: Who replaced Jehoahaz as king of Judah according to 2 Chronicles 36?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:4 states that the king of Egypt made Eliakim his brother king over Judah and Jerusalem and changed his name to Jehoiakim.

questions.question: What was the age of Jehoiakim when he began to reign, and how long did he reign?
options: Twenty-five years old, reigned eleven years
Twenty-three years old, reigned three months
Eight years old, reigned three months and ten days
Twenty-one years old, reigned eleven years
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty-five years old, reigned eleven years
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:5 notes that Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign and reigned eleven years in Jerusalem.

questions.question: What significant act did Nebuchadnezzar perform when he conquered Judah as detailed in this chapter?
options: Carried vessels of the house of the LORD to Babylon
Built a new temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Carried vessels of the house of the LORD to Babylon
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:7 records that Nebuchadnezzar took vessels from the house of the LORD to Babylon and placed them in his temple, highlighting Babylonian conquest and temple desecration.

questions.question: Which king was taken captive to Babylon after reigning only three months and ten days?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiachin
questions.explanation: According to 2 Chronicles 36:9-10, Jehoiachin reigned for three months and ten days before Nebuchadnezzar took him to Babylon.

questions.question: What was Zedekiah’s response to the prophet Jeremiah’s warnings, as described in this chapter?
options: He ignored and rebelled against the warnings
questions.correctAnswer: He ignored and rebelled against the warnings
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:12-13 indicates that Zedekiah did evil, did not humble himself before Jeremiah, and rebelled against Nebuchadnezzar despite his oath.

questions.question: What was the primary reason for the LORD sending messengers and prophets to Judah before the Babylonian exile?
options: Because He had compassion on His people and His dwelling place
To warn them about Egypt’s invasion
To announce the coming of Cyrus
To instruct them to build a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: Because He had compassion on His people and His dwelling place
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:15 explains that the LORD sent messengers early and often because of His compassion on His people and the temple.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the people to God’s messengers and prophets before the exile?
questions.correctAnswer: They mocked and despised them
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:16 states that the people mocked the messengers of God and misused His prophets, leading to the LORD’s wrath.

questions.question: What role does the seventy years of desolation mentioned in 2 Chronicles 36:21 play in biblical theology?
options: It fulfilled the land's sabbath rest as commanded in Leviticus
It symbolized the end of the Davidic covenant
It was the period of Egyptian domination over Judah
It marked the duration of Solomon’s temple construction
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfilled the land's sabbath rest as commanded in Leviticus
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:21 references the land keeping sabbath for seventy years, echoing Leviticus 25’s sabbatical year principle applied prophetically.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 36, which king issued a decree allowing the Israelites to return and rebuild the temple?
questions.correctAnswer: Cyrus
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:22-23 shows that Cyrus king of Persia proclaimed that the LORD had given him all kingdoms and commanded him to build a house in Jerusalem.

questions.question: Which literary device is strongly present in the structure of this chapter, considering the rise and fall of kings and the exile and restoration theme?
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm illustrating judgment and restoration
questions.explanation: The chapter’s structure shows a chiastic pattern with the kings’ failures leading to exile (judgment) and the decree of Cyrus (restoration), a common biblical literary form.

questions.question: Which king of Egypt is mentioned as having a direct influence on Judah’s monarchy in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Necho
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:3-4 mentions the king of Egypt, Necho, who deposed Jehoahaz and made Eliakim king, renaming him Jehoiakim.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The vessels of the house of the LORD were taken to Babylon and placed in __________ according to 2 Chronicles 36:7.
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadnezzar's temple
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:7 records that Nebuchadnezzar carried the vessels to Babylon and put them in his temple, symbolizing Babylonian dominance over Israel’s sacred items.

questions.question: True or False: Zedekiah humbled himself before the prophet Jeremiah and repented of his evil deeds.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 2 Chronicles 36:12 states that Zedekiah did evil and did not humble himself before Jeremiah, showing his rebellion against God's word.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the cultural and theological significance of the Babylonian exile as depicted in this chapter?
options: A divine punishment fulfilling prophetic warnings and sabbatical rest for the land
A political alliance formed between Babylon and Judah
An economic trade embargo by Babylon
A temporary relocation for strategic military purposes
questions.correctAnswer: A divine punishment fulfilling prophetic warnings and sabbatical rest for the land
questions.explanation: The chapter (especially verses 16-21) frames the exile as God's judgment for sin, fulfilling prophetic warnings and the sabbath rest for the land, emphasizing covenant faithfulness.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 36 relate intertextually to the book of Jeremiah?
options: It confirms the fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecies about exile and restoration
It only references Jeremiah’s life without prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms the fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecies about exile and restoration
questions.explanation: Verses 2 Chronicles 36:15-21 explicitly mention Jeremiah's prophecies and how their fulfillment is seen in the exile and later restoration under Cyrus.

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 36 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who was made king in Jerusalem after Josiah's death according to 2 Chronicles 36?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoahaz
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz, the son of Josiah, was made king in Jerusalem after Josiah's death as recorded in 2 Chronicles 36:1. This fits the biblical pattern of dynastic succession (1 Kings 2:12; 2 Kings 23:30).

questions.question: How long did Jehoahaz reign in Jerusalem before being deposed by the king of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Three months
questions.explanation: Jehoahaz reigned only three months in Jerusalem before being put down by the king of Egypt (2 Chronicles 36:2-3). Short reigns often reflect divine judgment (Psalm 89:30-33).

questions.question: What was imposed on the land when the king of Egypt deposed Jehoahaz?
options: One hundred talents of silver and one talent of gold
questions.correctAnswer: One hundred talents of silver and one talent of gold
questions.explanation: The king of Egypt condemned the land to pay a hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold (2 Chronicles 36:3). This shows the economic burden imposed by foreign powers (Exodus 12:35-36; 2 Kings 24:7).

questions.question: What new name was given to Eliakim when he was made king by the king of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoiakim
questions.explanation: Eliakim was renamed Jehoiakim when made king by the Egyptian king (2 Chronicles 36:4). Name changes often signify new roles or divine purposes (Genesis 17:5; Daniel 1:7).

questions.question: How did Jehoiakim reign in the sight of the LORD according to this chapter?
options: He did evil in the sight of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil in the sight of the LORD
questions.explanation: Jehoiakim is described as doing evil in the sight of the LORD (2 Chronicles 36:5). This reflects human sinfulness and rejection of God's covenant (Jeremiah 22:13-19; Romans 3:10-18).

questions.question: Which king brought Jehoiakim to Babylon in fetters?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadnezzar
questions.explanation: Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, bound Jehoiakim in fetters and carried him to Babylon (2 Chronicles 36:6). Babylonian captivity was a consequence of Israel's persistent disobedience (Jeremiah 25:9; Daniel 1:1-2).

questions.question: What was done with the vessels from the house of the LORD taken by Nebuchadnezzar?
options: They were placed in the temple at Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They were placed in the temple at Babylon
questions.explanation: Nebuchadnezzar took vessels of the house of the LORD and placed them in his temple at Babylon (2 Chronicles 36:7). This demonstrates the captivity and desecration of sacred items (Daniel 5:2; Ezra 1:7-11).

questions.question: At what age did Jehoiachin begin to reign, and how long was his reign?
options: Eight years old, three months and ten days
questions.correctAnswer: Eight years old, three months and ten days
questions.explanation: Jehoiachin began to reign at eight years old and reigned three months and ten days (2 Chronicles 36:9). This brief reign highlights the instability caused by sin and judgment (2 Kings 24:8-9).

questions.question: Who did Nebuchadnezzar appoint as king over Judah after taking Jehoiachin to Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Zedekiah
questions.explanation: Nebuchadnezzar made Zedekiah king over Judah after taking Jehoiachin to Babylon (2 Chronicles 36:10). God’s sovereignty is seen in using foreign rulers to fulfill His purposes (Isaiah 45:1; Daniel 4:17).

questions.question: What was Zedekiah's response to the prophet Jeremiah's warnings?
options: He humbled himself not before Jeremiah
He ignored Jeremiah but did not rebel
questions.correctAnswer: He humbled himself not before Jeremiah
questions.explanation: Zedekiah did evil and humbled himself not before Jeremiah, who spoke from the mouth of the LORD (2 Chronicles 36:12). This shows human stubbornness and rejection of divine correction (Proverbs 1:23-33; Hebrews 12:5-11).

questions.question: What was the consequence of the people's mocking and despising God's messengers?
options: The wrath of the LORD arose against His people till there was no remedy
God sent immediate destruction without warning
questions.correctAnswer: The wrath of the LORD arose against His people till there was no remedy
questions.explanation: Because the people mocked and despised the messengers of God, His wrath arose until there was no remedy (2 Chronicles 36:16). This illustrates divine justice and the seriousness of rejecting God's revelation (Hebrews 10:26-31; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: What did the king of the Chaldees do upon bringing judgment on Jerusalem?
options: Slew young men in the house of sanctuary without compassion
Offered mercy and peace to the people
Only took spoils but spared the people
questions.correctAnswer: Slew young men in the house of sanctuary without compassion
questions.explanation: The king of the Chaldees slew young men with the sword in the sanctuary and showed no compassion (2 Chronicles 36:17). This judgment was severe, fulfilling God's warnings against persistent sin (Jeremiah 52:12-14; Lamentations 2:13-16).

questions.question: What did the Babylonians do to the house of God and the city of Jerusalem?
options: Burnt the house of God and broke down the wall
Preserved the temple but took the people
Left the city intact but took treasures
Renovated the temple for their gods
questions.correctAnswer: Burnt the house of God and broke down the wall
questions.explanation: They burnt the house of God, broke down the wall, and burnt all the palaces of Jerusalem (2 Chronicles 36:19). This shows the total destruction as a result of covenant unfaithfulness (Jeremiah 52:13-14; Ezekiel 9:8-10:22).

questions.question: For how long were the people servants in Babylon according to this chapter?
options: Until the reign of the kingdom of Persia
Until the coming of the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: Until the reign of the kingdom of Persia
questions.explanation: Those who escaped were servants in Babylon until the reign of Persia (2 Chronicles 36:20). This period of exile was part of God's redemptive timeline (Jeremiah 29:10; Daniel 9:2).

questions.question: Why did the land keep sabbath and lie desolate for seventy years?
options: To fulfill the word of the LORD by Jeremiah
Because the people chose to rest
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill the word of the LORD by Jeremiah
questions.explanation: The land kept sabbath for seventy years to fulfill the LORD's word spoken by Jeremiah (2 Chronicles 36:21). This reflects God's justice and mercy in allowing land rest (Leviticus 25:1-7; 2 Kings 25:12).
